It is unlikely that China will establish an ADIZ in the South China Sea before 1 March 2021. China developed the necessary infrastructure for a South China ADIZ several years ago, however, they have yet to enact one.  While China can declare an ADIZ with little warning, this would be a significant departure from the status quo and likely be preceded by some other geopolitical event. As early as 2015, China built runways and high-frequency radar stations on several islands and reefs in the South China Sea.  Since this time, they have deployed airborne early warning aircraft, surface-to-air missile systems and anti-ship missile systems to these locations.  With these capabilities already in place, China could enact a new ADIZ with very little advance notice. China, Japan, South Vietnam, South Korea and the Philippines have all declared ADIZs at one time or another (South Vietnam’s and the Philippines’ are no longer active).  Each of these countries established an ADIZ after some major geopolitical event like the Korean War or Vietnam War.  China established the region’s most recent ADIZ in 2013 in the East China Sea.  China announced their intention in 2010 but did not actually establish the ADIZ until 2013, after Japan nationalized the disputed Senkaku Islands. Today, China has little to gain from proactively declaring an ADIZ in the South China Sea.  China and ASEAN re-entered talks for a South China Sea Code of Conduct in September 2020.  While the COVID Pandemic has delayed negotiation, China hopes to ratify an agreement sometime in 2021.  Proactively declaring an ADIZ would undoubtedly disrupt this process. Like in 2013, China may reactively declare an ADIZ if they feel another nation directly threatens their territorial claims.  This perspective is more in line with recent statements from pundits sympathetic to the CCP’s territorial claims.  With only 49 days until 1 March, I would assess the probability of such an event as low (8%).  China has already established a dominant position in the disputed islands of the South China Sea.  Competing nations have not telegraphed the intention or the ability to challenge China’s position in the near future. However, a South China Sea ADIZ may also be a collateral effect of China’s diplomatic position with Taiwan.  On 9 January 2021, the U.S. Secretary of State lifted all self-imposed diplomatic restrictions with Taiwan, a move China views as highly provocative.  Although not directly tied to Taiwan, China may enact a South China Sea ADIZ to assert their dominance in the region early in the Biden Administration’s term in office.  For this reason, I’ll increase my forecast by  another 3%, for an overall probability of 11%.

China announced its first ADIZ in the East China Sea in November 2013. At that time Chinese Ministry of Defense’ spokesman proclaimed, “China will establish other air defense identification zones at an appropriate time after completing preparations.” It seems clear China intends to do this eventually, but it’s unclear what are the prerequisites are before it takes this action. According to Defense.com, “this is a lesson that China has learnt from its ECS ADIZ experience; any ADIZ would need to be backed with credible systems and capabilities before China can declare the region ADIZ.” It is unclear to me whether this is actually a prerequisite for China. It is also unclear what China’s assessment is of its capabilities in the region are vis-a-vis the potential to defend the declaration of the ADIZ.  In November 2020, the Beijing-based SCS Strategic Situation Probing Initiative said the international community’s perception that China would set up an ADIZ over the disputed waters – as it did in the East China Sea seven years ago – was a “misinterpretation”. The guest commentary by Chang Ching, a research fellow at the Society for Strategic Studies in Taipei, said even though the US had stepped up military activities in the area in recent years, China had no need to respond by declaring an ADIZ. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3111204/south-china-sea-beijing-doesnt-want-upset-neighbours-air  On the other hand, a Taiwanese analyst says “PLA intrusions in Taiwan’s ADIZ since September have made up for more than 30 percent of the whole year” and takes this an an indication China is close to establishing its own ADIZ Southeastof Taiwan and the Pratas Islands. https://thediplomat.com/2020/11/is-china-preparing-to-set-up-an-adiz-in-the-south-china-sea-with-taiwan-in-mind/ Ultimately given the time remaining, it’s unlikely that this will occur, but the turbulence following the U.S. election would seem an opportune time for China to act.

China declared an ADIZ in the East China Sea in In November 2013.  According to a 2017 RAND study, "an ADIZ exists in international airspace but does not grant the declaring state sovereignty over that airspace, which is governed by international law. What gives a state the right to require foreign aircraft to comply with identification procedures in international airspace? According to the Judge Advocate General’s School: ADIZs are legally justified on the basis that a nation has the right to establish reasonable conditions of entry into its national airspace. Accordingly, an aircraft approaching national airspace may be required to identify itself while in international airspace as a condition of entry approval."  (https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR2055.html) China received a lot of backlash for establishing the East China Sea ADIZ and most nations have completely ignored it.  While some sources claim China has wanted to set up a SCS ADIZ since 2010, a quick Google Search revealed some recent discussions about China declaring an ADIZ in the SCS, (https://thediplomat.com/2020/11/is-china-preparing-to-set-up-an-adiz-in-the-south-china-sea-with-taiwan-in-mind/) and (https://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/southchinasea-adiz-06022020194134.html), but I just do not see enough information to warrant a belief that this is going to happen anytime before 1 March.    If there was some type of issue with an American military plane violating China's territorial airspace, I could see the need for them to announce this sooner than later.  Also, I don't think the incoming Biden administration intends to be "tough" on China, so China would be foolish to ratchet up tension with a new administration.

There are 3 months to go. On Wikipedia I found that the first ADIZ was established 70 years ago, and that there are ~30 of them today (counting expansions of existing ones) [1]. This count is uncertain as I couldn't find a real list anywhere. In any case, that makes for an ~11% average chance that an ADIZ will be created or expanded somewhere in any given 3-month period. However this question is about one specific ADIZ, so the base rate for that is lower. Another base rate: China had been considering the East China ADIZ since at least Dec 2007, and it finally was implemented in 2013, 6 years later. That puts the average rate of ADIZ creation/expansion in China at less than 6% every 3 months. So let's call the base rate for this event, 8%. INSIDE VIEW
This specific ADIZ is more controversial than the average ADIZ in that it covers an area that other countries claim. On the other hand, some in the defense community have noted that China expanded into the SCS in a big way, building bases, ports and whatnot; and put this forward as evidence that they will declare ADIZ there. Of course, for X to be evidence for Y, we need to consider also the chance that X happens even when Y doesn't. In this case, China could be expanding into SCS even without the intention of declaring ADIZ. So here is my simple bayesian calculation. We noted above that the raw probability of ADIZ in the next 3 months is P[ADIZ] = 0.08. We want the probability of ADIZ in the next 3 months, *given that* China is doing all this expansion, P[ADIZ|expansion]. I estimate P[expansion|ADIZ] to be 0.95; if they were planning to do ADIZ they would almost certainly be expanding. Otoh I estimate P[expansion|no ADIZ] to be 0.7. Even if they were not planning ADIZ in the next 3 months, they might still be planning it later (so expansion is still needed), or they might be expanding for non-ADIZ reasons. This means that the raw P[expansion] is 0.95*0.08 + 0.7*0.92 = 0.72. So by Bayes' theorem we have P[ADIZ|expansion] = P[expansion|ADIZ]*P[ADIZ]/P[expansion] = 0.95*0.08/0.72 ~ 11%. The part that I'm least sure about is P[expansion|no ADIZ], so it's reassuring that the final estimate is not that sensitive to it, because the base rate P[ADIZ] is so low. If I had used P[expansion|no ADIZ]=0.5 instead, I would get 13% instead of 11%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_defense_identification_zone
[2] https://defense.info/global-dynamics/2020/08/will-china-declare-an-air-defense-identification-zone-in-south-china-sea/

It is difficult to identify a base rate for this event because there has only been one other China example, the ECS ADIZ. Additionally, the circumstances of that event are very different. However, information from the ECS ADIZ declaration can aid as a potential indicator of China actions. The ECS ADIZ caused a lot of angst for all parties, China included. Although China might be consider themselves as overall successful in establishing the ECS ADIZ, they were not initially prepared to enforce the ADIZ. Therefore, China may not establish a SCS ADIZ until they are feel prepared to enforce. PRC messaging indicates that there may be plans already developed to eventually declare an ADIZ over parts of the SCS, when they are prepared. It is difficult to determine what level of preparedness China requires prior to establishing the SCS ADIZ. Perhaps, they are already prepared and are waiting for the appropriate time to make an announcement. They do have multiple air bases established in the SCS with defensive systems, therefore, it seems logical to suggest that they may be close to readiness level necessary to enforce an ADIZ. The ECS ADIZ was announced in November of 2013 and overlaps other countries ADIZs. Any extension of the ECS ADIZ or the declaration of new ADIZ will cause significant international attention. With only one other China example, it might be necessary to expand to other states that have established ADIZs. However, these events are very infrequent and don’t exhibit clear patterns. Any increased tension in the SCS or significant opposition or challenge to China in the SCS will increase the likelihood of an SCS ADIZ. Currently, through opensource information, there doesn’t seem to be any indicator of China’s motive to declare a new or updated ADIZ.

China established an ADIZ in the East China Sea in 2013. At the time the Chinese Ministry of Defense’ spokesman proclaimed, “China will establish other air defense identification zones at an appropriate time after completing preparations.” (nationalinterest.org)  However, given that China has elected not to take such a provocative step during the entire Trump Presidency (where the US was trying to push-back fairly hard against China, and the [US administration] alleged inequality with trade and tariffs).  I assess that there is a very low chance that China would seek to destabilize potentially beneficial (to China) improved relations with the anticipated (new) Biden administration, by carrying out such a provocative strategic move.

In general, the PRC likes to make broad pronouncements at major party congresses (the 19th party Congress is in 2022). The PRC also seems inclined to make declarations when overtly threatened by the US or another nation. This seems less likely given the US election result and Chinese officials statements vis-a-vis a Biden vs Trump administration. I suspect that Xi Jinping's administration will wait to see what the Biden administration's policy in regard to China are before taking proactive actions like declaring an ADIZ (this would only be 40 days into a new presidency). The PRC's foreign minister greeted the election result positively. Much of the antagonism that has driven Chinese declarations in the South China Sea has been related to US Naval Patrols, which seem unlikely in the current environment in the US after the firing of the Defense Secretary and during a probable election transition. The PRC has only declared a single ADIZ since its inception over the East China Sea in 2013. This is such a rare event that a frequentist model is useless. The PRC officially holds that the South China Sea islands are the sovereign territory of China much as was claimed about the East China Sea islands. Both claims have been met with skepticism internationally. Conversely, if another rare event were to occur like a Trump surprise victory in the US election then this would increase the likelihood of this event as the PRC sees Trump's position as more clearly anti-PRC and the chaos in the US from a highly contested election would give the PRC more room to maneuver internationally to avoid sanctions from such a declaration. Thus, without a party platform for this announcement, without an overt international reason driving its immediacy, lacking overt antagonism by its main rival, but with the possibility for a rare event to destabilize this situation I would estimate a probability of around 20.0% per year. Given that the portion of the year subtended in the question period is 29.86%, I would estimate a 5.97% probability of this occurring.
